contentrichtext.text: [[File:Aistulf follis 80000860.jpg|thumb|A ''[[follis]]'' of Aistulf]] '''Aistulf''' (died 756) was the [[Duke of Friuli]] from 744, King of [[Lombards]] from 749, and [[Duchy of Spoleto|Duke of Spoleto]] from 751. His father was the [[Pemmo of Friuli|Duke Pemmo]]. After his brother [[Ratchis]] became king, Aistulf succeeded him in Friuli. He succeeded him later as king when Ratchis abdicated to a monastery. Aistulf continued the policy of expansion and raids against the [[papacy]] and the [[Byzantine Empire|Byzantine]] [[exarchate of Ravenna]]. In 751, he captured [[Ravenna]] itself and even threatened [[Rome]], claiming a [[head tax|capitation tax]]. he also conquered [[Istria]] region from Byzantines in same year. The popes, thoroughly irritated and alarmed, and hopeless of aid from the Byzantine Emperor, turned to the [[Carolingian]] [[mayors of the palaces|mayors of the palace]] of [[Austrasia]], the effective rulers of the [[Franks|Frankish kingdom]]. In 741, [[Pope Gregory III]] asked [[Charles Martel]] to intervene, but he was too busy elsewhere and declined. In 753, [[Pope Stephen II]] visited Charles Martel's son [[Pepin the Short|Pippin the Short]], who had been proclaimed king of the Franks in 751 with the consent of [[Pope Zachary]]. In gratitude for the papal consent to his coronation, Pippin crossed the [[Alps]], defeated Aistulf, and gave to the pope the lands which Aistulf had torn from the ''ducatus Romanus'' and the exarchate ([[Emilia-Romagna]] and the [[Pentapolis]]). Aistulf died hunting in 756. He was succeeded by [[Desiderius]] as king of the Lombards and by [[Alboin of Spoleto|Alboin]] as duke of [[Spoleto]]. He had given Friuli to his brother-in-law [[Anselm, Duke of Friuli|Anselm]], abbot of [[Nonantula]], whose sister Gisaltruda he had married, when he succeeded to the kingship in 749.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.germantribes.org/tribes/Lombards/Lombard%20Rulers/kingsline.htm | title = German Tribes org Lombard Kings | work = GermanTribes.org | archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20100718043340/http://www.germantribes.org/tribes/Lombards/Lombard%20Rulers/kingsline.htm | archivedate = 2010-07-18 | accessdate = 2010-07-18 }}</ref> ==References== {{more footnotes|date=September 2008}} {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{Cite CE1913|wstitle=Aistulph|first=Ewan |last=Macpherson |volume=1}} *{{Cite AmCyc|wstitle=Astolphus}} {{s-start}} {{s-reg}} {{s-bef|rows=2|before=[[Ratchis]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[List of dukes and margraves of Friuli|Duke of Friuli]]|years=744–749}} {{s-aft|after=[[Anselm, Duke of Friuli|Anselm]]}} |- {{s-ttl|title=[[List of kings of the Lombards|King of the Lombards]]|years=749–756}} {{s-aft|after=[[Desiderius]]}} {{s-bef|before=[[Unulf of Spoleto|Unnolf]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[List of Dukes of Spoleto|Duke of Spoleto]]|years=751–756}} {{s-aft|after=[[Alboin of Spoleto|Alboin]]}} {{end}} {{Antique Kings of Italy}} {{Persondata | NAME = Aistulf | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = Duke of Friuli | DATE OF BIRTH = | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = 756 | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Aistulf}} [[Category:756 deaths]] [[Category:Lombard kings]] [[Category:Dukes of Friuli]] [[Category:Dukes of Spoleto]] [[Category:Lombard people]] [[Category:8th-century Italian people]] [[Category:8th-century monarchs in Europe]] [[Category:Year of birth unknown]]
